subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] new course for MemRise; new decks for ANKI
msgSnippet: Scott, Alright!  Well, right there you ve given me plenty!  I will almost certainly want to pepper this discussion group with questions for you, if you don t
messageBody:
Scott,

Alright!  Well, right there you've given me plenty!  I will almost certainly want to pepper this discussion group with questions for you, if you don't mind.

One question is, what software did you use for creating or modifying the fonts?

Another,  well that special uppercase key ("pipe") is not mapped to the "awe" letter.  It's just pipe.  Now, really, I could probably go a long time without it.

Yes, I agree with you about the half letters and the ligatures.  Kerining does not sound like fun!  

This Yahoo site comes at a good place for me.  King Plus Monospace is a very good font for learning Junior QS (section I of the manual).   Now, I believe I'll switch to Suave for Section II (your script is great with readable abbreviations) and perhaps Junior or Jerome for Section III (where I can at least simulate written QS).

Sincerely,

Ben



On Tuesday, September 29, 2015 7:24 PM, "Scott Ellsworth scott@... [Read_Alphabet]" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:


 
Hello Ben,
 
I'm glad you like the Suave font. I created it to serve my own needs and preferences, and then thought I should share it. It doesn't seem to work perfectly with every version of every program, but it's the best I could manage with my limited knowledge and without a fancier font-editing program. Actually, all the full letters are present, though not all of them are mapped to the keyboard. The "awe" letter is located on the key where the "|" resides -- that's the same key I used for the accent mark, but the "awe" is uppercase (using the Shift key). This sound does not exist in my pronunciation, so I wanted to keep it out of the way, off to the side. But I kept it on the keyboard in case I might need it for some reason. The other letters you can find and input with the character map. So in LibreOffice, Insert > Special Character (shortcut: Alt-I, P). You'll see the X's, the degree sign, the euro sign, etc. To get some of those more quickly, you can try using Autocorrect and perhaps macros. (I personally use Autocorrect to obtain an accented "i" since that letter doesn't always line up right with an accent mark.)
 
I didn't include the half-letters because it seemed to me that they would be a lot of extra work to keep track of when typing. They would also add a tremendous amount of work with creating new "kerning pairs," so that they would line up properly with other letters. I tried to optimize the font for easy typing, while in my handwriting I use all the features of Senior Quikscript. So this ended up being a bit of a compromise: Junior Quikscript seems better suited to typing; but at the same time, I got used to how the letters neatly nest together in handwriting, so I created hundreds of kerning pairs in the font so that would happen at least most of the time.
 
I personally have no experience with conversion utilities. I was curious about Adapt-It but never got around to trying it out. 
 
Enjoy,
 
Scott
 
 
<<<< Scott Ellsworth -- phone 415-621-6148 >>>>
 
 
----- Original message -----
From: "trybloganatgmail@... [Read_Alphabet]" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com>
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] new course for MemRise; new decks for ANKI
Date: 29 Sep 2015 11:49:50 -0700
Yes, thank you.  I myself don't understand the conflict with Shavian Script.  It is attractive, but it does not have all the dips and swoops that make QuickScript easier (in my mind) to read and write.  But, what do I know?
 
I've looking at the several fonts available at the site.  Each one has particular strengths.  Suave (swxv) appears to meet my needs in an American font.  However, there does not appear to be an "aw" letter, unless "ox" in American English is close enough.
 
Everyone has their personal reasons for preferring one or another.  I might try to do without half letters and with fewer ligatures for the time being, as Ellsworth recommends.  And eventually, I'll see what happens to my reading ability.  If you know how to contact him, please let me know.  I've got questions.
 
For some perhaps minor reason, Suave--out of all fonts I've looked at--appears to look most like phonetic English if converted to Ariel or whatever.  A little minor search and replaces in LibreOffice, and I'm pretty good to go.
 
One other item:  Is it possible to find the source code for that wonderful QS_Converter?  Are the Perl Scripts in another folder related?  This brings up an interesting question for me.  How well could it convert from QS back to English?   What percentage of errors would I find?

<html><body><div style=3D"color:#000; background-color:#fff; font-family:He=
lveticaNeue, Helvetica Neue, Helvetica, Arial, Lucida Grande, sans-serif;fo=

n></div><div id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_3192"><span><br></span></div>=
<div id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_2758"><span id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_144363=
1471500_2797">Alright!  Well, right there you've given me plenty! &nbs=
p;I will almost certainly want to pepper this discussion group with questio=
ns for you, if you don't mind.</span></div><div id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_14436314=
71500_2758"><span><br></span></div><div id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_27=
58"><span id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_3208">One question is, what soft=
ware did you use for creating or modifying the fonts?</span></div><div id=
=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_2758"><span><br></span></div><div id=3D"yui_=
3_16_0_1_1443631471500_2758"><span id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_3134">A=
nother,  well that special uppercase key ("pipe") is not mapped to the=
 "awe" letter.  It's just pipe.  Now, really, I could probably go=
 a long time without it.</span></div><div id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_=
2758"><span><br></span></div><div id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_2758"><s=
pan id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_3178">Yes, I agree with you about the =
half letters and the ligatures.  Kerining does not sound like fun! &nb=
sp;</span></div><div id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_2758"><span><br></spa=
n></div><div id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_2758"><span id=3D"yui_3_16_0_=
1_1443631471500_3795">This Yahoo site comes at a good place for me.  K=
ing Plus Monospace is a very good font for learning Junior QS (section I of=
 the manual).   Now, I believe I'll switch to Suave for Section II (yo=
ur script is great with readable abbreviations) and perhaps Junior or Jerom=
e for Section III (where I can at least simulate written QS).</span></div><=
div id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_2758" dir=3D"ltr"><span><br></span></d=
iv><div id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_2758" dir=3D"ltr"><span id=3D"yui_=
3_16_0_1_1443631471500_4691">Sincerely,</span></div><div id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1=

_4698">Ben</span></div>  <br><div class=3D"qtdSeparateBR"><br><br></div><di=
v class=3D"yahoo_quoted" style=3D"display: block;"> <div style=3D"font-fami=

rif; font-size: 16px;"> <div style=3D"font-family: HelveticaNeue, Helvetica=
 Neue, Helvetica, Arial, Lucida Grande, sans-serif; font-size: 16px;"> <div=
 dir=3D"ltr"> <font size=3D"2" face=3D"Arial"> On Tuesday, September 29, 20=
15 7:24 PM, "Scott Ellsworth scott@... [Read_Alphabet]" <Read_Al=
phabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:<br> </font> </div>  <br><br> <div class=

<div id=3D"yiv0658949360ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"">
  <=

    <div id=3D"yiv0658949360=
ygrp-text">
      
      
      <div>


</div><div>Hello Ben,<br clear=3D"n=
one"></div>
<div> </div>
<div>I'm glad you like the Suave font. I crea=
ted it to serve my own needs and preferences, and then thought I should sha=
re it. It doesn't seem to work perfectly with every version of every progra=
m, but it's the best I could manage with my limited knowledge and without a=
 fancier font-editing program. Actually, all the full letters are present, =
though not all of them are mapped to the keyboard. The "awe" letter is loca=
ted on the key where the "|" resides -- that's the same key I used for the =
accent mark, but the "awe" is uppercase (using the Shift key). This sound d=
oes not exist in my pronunciation, so I wanted to keep it out of the way, o=
ff to the side. But I kept it on the keyboard in case I might  need it for =
some reason. The other letters you can find and input with the character ma=
p. So in LibreOffice, Insert > Special Character (shortcut: Alt-I, P). Y=
ou'll see the X's, the degree sign, the euro sign, etc. To get some of thos=
e more quickly, you can try using Autocorrect and perhaps macros. (I person=
ally use Autocorrect to obtain an accented "i" since that letter doesn't al=
ways line up right with an accent mark.)<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div>&nbs=
p;</div>
<div>I didn't include the half-letters because it seemed to me tha=
t they would be a lot of extra work to keep track of when typing. They woul=
d also add a tremendous amount of work with creating new "kerning pairs," s=
o that they would line up properly with other letters. I tried to optimize =
the font for easy typing, while in my handwriting I  use all the features o=
f Senior Quikscript. So this ended up being a bit of a compromise: Junior Q=
uikscript seems better suited to typing; but at the same time, I got used t=
o how the letters neatly nest together in handwriting, so I created hundred=
s of kerning pairs in the font so that would happen at least most of the ti=
me.<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div> </div>
<div>I personally have no ex=
perience with conversion utilities. I was curious about Adapt-It but never =
got around to trying it out. <br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div> </di=
v>
<div>Enjoy,<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div> </div>
<div>Scott</div>
=
<div> </div>
<div id=3D"yiv0658949360sig4325065"><div class=3D"yiv0658=
949360signature"> </div>
<div class=3D"yiv0658949360signature"><&lt=
;<< Scott Ellsworth -- phone 415-621-6148 >>>><br cl=
ear=3D"none"></div>
</div>
<div> </div>
<div> </div>
<div>----- O=
riginal message -----<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div>From: "<a rel=3D"nofoll=
ow" shape=3D"rect" ymailto=3D"mailto:trybloganatgmail@..." target=3D"=
_blank" href=3D"mailto:trybloganatgmail@...">trybloganatgmail@yahoo.c=
om</a> [Read_Alphabet]" <<a rel=3D"nofollow" shape=3D"rect" ymailto=3D"m=
ailto:Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"mailto:Read_=
Alphabet@yahoogroups.com">Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com</a>><br clear=3D=
"none"></div>
<div>To: <a rel=3D"nofollow" shape=3D"rect" ymailto=3D"mailto=
:Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"mailto:Read_Alpha=
bet@yahoogroups.com">Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com</a><br clear=3D"none"></=
div>
<div>Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] new course for MemRise; new decks fo=
r ANKI<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div>Date: 29 Sep 2015 11:49:50 -0700<br cl=
ear=3D"none"></div>
<div>Yes, thank you.  I myself don't understand th=
e conflict with Shavian Script.  It is attractive, but it does not hav=
e all the dips and swoops that make QuickScript easier (in my mind) to read=
 and write.  But, what do I know?<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div style=
=3D"font-family:Arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif;font-size:13px;"><div><=
div style=3D"font-family:Georgia;"><div> </div>
<div>I've looking at t=
he several fonts available at the site.  Each one has particular stren=
gths.  Suave (swxv) appears to meet my needs in an American font. &nbs=
p;However, there does not appear to be an "aw" letter, unless "ox" in Ameri=
can English is close enough.<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div> </div>
<di=
v>Everyone has their personal reasons for preferring one or another.  =
I might try to do without half letters and with fewer ligatures for the tim=
e being, as Ellsworth recommends.  And eventually, I'll see what happe=
ns to my reading ability.  If you know how to contact him, please let =
me know.  I've got questions.<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div> </di=
v>
<div>For some perhaps minor reason, Suave--out of all fonts I've looked =
at--appears to look most like phonetic English if converted to Ariel or wha=
tever.  A little minor search and replaces in LibreOffice, and I'm pre=
tty good to go.<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div> </div>
<div>One other i=
tem:  Is it possible to find the source code for that wonderful QS_Con=
verter?  Are the Perl Scripts in another folder related?  This br=
ings up an interesting question for me.  How well could it convert fro=
m QS back to English?   What percentage of errors would I find?<br cle=
ar=3D"none"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div> </div>




    </div>
  =
